summary:
We need to produce JSON with summary, business_intent, keywords list.

We must not list function names verbatim. So we need to describe module responsibility: It acts as an adapter to map old URL patterns to new upstream URL structure for Open Library Infobase. Provides request handling hooks for various HTTP methods (GET, POST, etc.) and reindex, save, etc., with pre/post processing. It also includes utility functions for key conversion (unused). Business intent: to provide compatibility layer for upstream clients expecting new URL schema while using existing Infobase API, enabling seamless migration and proxying. Keywords: adapter, URL rewriting, proxy, Open Library, Infobase, request preprocessing, postprocessing, reindex, save, bulk operations, versioning, key conversion.

Make sure not to list function names verbatim. So we can refer to "account management", "GET handling", etc., but not function names.

Let's craft summary: The module implements a filter that sits in front of the Infobase server, translating incoming requests that use the new upstream URL patterns (/user/, /b/, /a/) into the legacy paths (/people/, /books/, /authors/). It defines a set of request‑handling classes that wrap the core Infobase operations (read, write, bulk, reindex, versioned access) and inject pre‑ and post‑processing hooks. It also contains helper utilities for converting between the old and new key formats, though they are currently unused.

Business intent: Provide backward‑compatible API surface for external services that rely on the newer upstream URL scheme, allowing Open Library to expose the same data without modifying the underlying Infobase implementation, and to centralize request preprocessing, error handling, and proxying logic.

Keywords list.

Now produce JSON.

Make sure to start with {{ and end with }} as per example. Provide valid JSON.

Let's craft.

assistantfinal{{"summary": "This module acts as a compatibility layer that intercepts HTTP requests destined for the Open Library Infobase, rewrites the newer upstream URL patterns (/user/, /b/, /a/) to the legacy paths (/people/, /books/, /authors/), and forwards them to the underlying service. It supplies a collection of request‑handling components that wrap core operations such as fetching single or multiple resources, saving records, bulk saves, reindexing, and versioned access, each with hooks for preprocessing and post‑processing. Additional utilities for converting between the old and new key formats are
